abstract.text: The anticommons in knowledge is distinct from the anticommons in physical objects.
The former is always tragic, the latter not necessarily so.
For society at large, the tragedy of the anticommons is more serious when it involves knowledge than when it involves physical resources.

Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) formal model of the anticommons is incorrect even within the neoclassical context, and their neoliberal suggestion that single ownership is the socially optimal solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons is misleading.
This article argues that the only, epistemically and socially beneficial solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons is to create, expand, and protect the knowledge commons.
The article also constructs a simple formal model based on Bessen and Maskin's (2006) sequential model, as a metaphor for how the comedy of the knowledge commons works.
The analysis supports the worldwide movement for free knowledge, and dissents from the evolving political and academic consensus in China in favor of more restrictive intellectual property regimes.

body_text.text: Dual to the concept "commons" 3 is the concept "anticommons."
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The idea was popularized in a 1998 article by Michael Heller published in the Harvard Law Review entitled "The Tragedy of the Anticommons: Property in the Transition from Marx to Markets."
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: According to the article, Frank Michelman appeared to have coined the term "anticommons" by introducing the equivalent of an anticommons through his speculative definition of a "regulatory regime" in his 1982 article challenging the presumptive efficiency of private property, 4 where he defined a "regulatory regime" to be a type of property "in which everyone always has rights respecting the objects in the regime, and no one, consequently, is ever privileged to use any of them except as particularly authorized by the others."
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This definition is based upon a kind of logical duality: "[i]f a regime exists in which all are privileged to use whatever objects they wish and in which no one holds exclusionary rights (that is, a commons), then, as a matter of logic, an anticommons also could exist where no one is privileged to use objects and everyone has the right to exclude" (Heller 1998).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: According to Heller (1998) there are only a few hypothetical examples for which an anticommons under Michelman's definition, which precludes use of the property by anyone, is the most efficient property regime.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Heller (1998) finds that "for most resources that people care about, some level of use is preferable to non-use, and an anticommons regime is a threat to, rather than the epitome of, optimal use."
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: He concludes that "[a]nticommons property is prone to the tragedy of underuse."
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is Heller who coined the term "tragedy of the anticommons" (Heller 2008: 18, 21).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As a practical matter Epstein (2009) noted that the holdout problem, one of the potential outcomes in an anticommons, has long been a concern of public policy makers.

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: While Heller and Eisenberg (1998) and Heller (2008: 76-78) warned that the privatization of biomedical research "risks creating a tragedy of the anticommons through a proliferation of fragmented and overlapping intellectual property rights," they did not generalize their criticism of intellectual property rights.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Instead they claimed that the tragedy of underuse arising out of the biomedical anticommons "is distinct from the routine underuse inherent in any well-functioning patent system."
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This article challenges that delimitation, and argues that intellectual property per se is the very source of the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge and that the tragedy is unavoidable so long as an intellectual property regime exists.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The rest of this article is organized as follows.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The second section analyzes both the anticommons in knowledge, which is distinct from the anticommons in physical objects, and the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This is followed by a third section that refutes the neoliberal argument that single ownership is the socially optimal solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The fourth section argues that the only epistemically and socially beneficial solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons is to create, expand, and protect the knowledge commons.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the fifth section, a simple model based on Bessen and Maskin's (2006) sequential model is constructed as a metaphor for how the comedy of the knowledge commons works.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The last section is the conclusion.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The concept of the anticommons can be traced back to at least as early as 1838.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In that year Antoine Augustin Cournot published his Researches into the Mathematical Principles of the Theory of Wealth, which included his "complementary monopoly" theory (Sonnenschein 1968;Heller 2008: 42).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Hugo Sonnenschein in a 1968 article demonstrated a formal duality between Cournot's theory of duopoly and his theory of complementary monopoly (Sonnenschein 1968;Feinberg and Kamien 2001;Gardner, Gaston, and Masson 2002).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Nirvikar Singh and Xavier Vives in a 1984 article provided a general treatment of the duality between Cournot competition and Bertrand competition, showing that oligopolists selling complementary products will choose to compete over price rather than output (Singh and Vives 1984;Gardner, Gaston, and Masson 2002).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The methodology these and other researches provided has been adopted by some scholars for investigating the regime of anticommons and for economic modeling of the anticommons.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: These formal economic models for analyzing anticommons and the tragedy of the anticommons in physical objects may also give clues about anticommons and the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For example, the simultaneous anticommons problem illustrated in Coloma's (2003) model, which corrected and reformulated Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) formal model within the neoclassical context, may be also used as a metaphor for one of the two mechanisms by which an anticommons might be created in biomedical research-by creating too many concurrent fragments of intellectual property rights in potential future products (e.g. the existence of separate patents on complementary gene fragments) (Heller and Eisenberg 1998;Landes and Posner 2003: 316), and the sequential anticommons problem illustrated in the model in Parisi, Schulz, and Depoorter (2004) and Schulz, Parisi, and Depoorter (2002) may be also used as a metaphor for the other mechanism-by permitting too many upstream patent owners to stack licenses on top of the future discoveries of downstream users (Heller and Eisenberg 1998).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Despite some insights, the existing formal economic models for analyzing the anticommons have limited explanatory power.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: They fail to address the full scope of anticommons problems in physical objects.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Furthermore, the models are basically designed for explaining an anticommons in physical objects and therefore miss some of the distinctive problems related to an anticommons in knowledge.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: First, the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge is much more severe than in physical objects, because of the idiosyncratic nature of knowledge: the existence of substantial, widespread, and even ubiquitous positive knowledge externalities, which will be significantly inhibited by the regime of anticommons.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The essence of knowledge creation is a course of systematic, indivisible, continuous, and dynamic development.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: An intellectual property regime, however, tries to break up such a course into fragments of intellectual monopolies.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In the words of Michael Polanyi, "[i]t tries to parcel up a stream of creative thought into a series of distinct claims, each of which is to constitute the basis of a separately owned monopoly," and tries to divide up "the growth of human knowledge. . .into such sharply circumscribed phases" (Polanyi 1944;Machlup 1958).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In that case, each owner, i.e. the monopolist of each fragment of "knowledge," has the right to exclude others from using that fragment, and thus no one will have the freedom to use the whole stream of that "knowledge."
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The anticommons in knowledge so created poses a dire threat to the growth of human knowledge.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For example, as Heller and Eisenberg (1998) mentioned, "[p]rivatization of upstream biomedical research in the United States may create anticommons property that is less visible than empty storefronts but even more economically and socially costly."
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Second, when there are significant pervasive negative externalities of use of physical resources, an anticommons in physical objects may be a better regime for social welfare because of less use of the resources, whereas with an anticommons in knowledge that is not the case.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The loss of positive externalities from an anticommons in knowledge creation is unlikely to be offset by reductions in the negative externalities accompanying knowledge creation.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: As neoliberals always ignore or downplay externalities, 8 Buchanan and Yoon (2000) did not consider externalities in their model for commons and anticommons.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Coloma (2003) corrected and improved Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) model within the neoclassical context, taking externalities into account for the problem of the commons by introducing a specific cost function.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: But his model only considered a so-called reciprocal externality, which is a localized negative externality.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: He did not consider negative externalities on environments outside the commons property, which are pervasive negative externalities.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For the problem of the anticommons, his model considered neither the localized negative externalities nor the pervasive negative externalities.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: When negative externalities are pervasive and significant, as is often the case, less use of the resources as a result of the anticommons regime than the "efficient" quantity determined in either Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) or Coloma's (2003) model may be better for social welfare.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In some circumstances, even no use of resources as a result of an anticommons regime under Michelman's definition 9 may be the best use.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Two examples of the latter are Robert Ellickson's hypothetical wilderness preserve, which "'any person' has standing to enforce," and James Krier's hypothetical nuclear-waste dump, which is so dangerous that everyone "has standing to exclude" (Heller 1998: 667, 668, note 214, note 215, and note 216).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For "knowledge," however, there are never any of the above-mentioned pervasive negative externalities.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For an anticommons in physical objects, "less use" is not necessarily "underuse" and in some circumstances even no use may be the best use, which may be called "the comedy of the anticommons" (Heller 2008: 46, 47).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For an anticommons in knowledge, "less use" is necessarily the "underuse," thus becoming tragic.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Finally, when pervasive negative externalities of use of physical resources are minor, possible coordination and cooperation between multiple owners (excluders) in an anticommons in physical objects may reduce the extent of underuse, but the underuse will not be eliminated; for an anticommons in knowledge, on the other hand, not only is there the underuse that such coordination and cooperation will not be able to eliminate, but much more importantly, such "cooperation" will inhibit the positive knowledge externalities to a greater extent.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Both Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) and Coloma's (2003) model only applied non-cooperative games in analyzing the commons and anticommons problems, without considering the cases of cooperative games.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In reality, however, there exists the potential for coordination and cooperation between multiple owners (excluders) in an anticommons, "with success more likely within close-knit communities than among hostile strangers" (Heller and Eisenberg 1998;Heller 1998: 625, and note 17).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: 10 When pervasive negative externalities are minor, such cooperation, if successful, will improve social welfare by reducing the extent of underuse.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The result of the successful cooperation may be an equilibrium where these owners' (excluders') total surplus is maximized, the same as the equilibrium under the single ownership, where the single owner's total surplus is maximized, as shown by Buchanan and Yoon (2000).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) analysis suggested that the equilibrium under either the single ownership or efficient collective management is socially optimal, but the suggestion is incorrect even according to neoclassical standards.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The equilibrium point, with less quantity supplied and higher price, actually deviates from the "true," socially optimal point, where the average revenue given by the demand function is equal to the social marginal cost, as shown in Coloma's (2003) model, which corrected and reformulated Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) model within the neoclassical context.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: 11 The deviation derives from the market power that the single owner has or the multiple owners 9 Heller (1998) defined anticommons property as "a property regime in which multiple owners hold effective rights of exclusion in a scarce resource."
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The distinction between Michelman's and Heller's (1998) definition is important.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The former can be understood as an open-access anticommons, which Robert C. Ellickson argued may be rare and for which a threshold requirement of "near simultaneous unanimous consent," which will be nearly impossible to achieve, ensures that the property will not be used by anyone (Heller 1998).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The latter can be understood as a limited-access anticommons, in which a limited group of owners have rights of exclusion and which Ellickson argued appears more often (See Heller 1998: 667, 668, 669, and note 218).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In the commons/anticommons duality, it is obvious that an open-access anticommons and a limited-access anticommons correspond to an open-access commons and a limited-access commons respectively.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: RSAS (2009), for example, mentioned the cases of "open access" and "a fixed number of users" for a commons.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: 10 Obviously, an anticommons in a close-knit community is a limited-access anticommons.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: 11 Coloma (2003) pointed out that in fact the tragedy of the commons does not exist in Buchanan and Yoon's (2000) model aimed at illustrating both the commons tragedy and the anticommons tragedy, because their model does not include any cost function.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Instead, Coloma's (2003) model introduces a cost function for each owner (user) such that each owner's (user's) private marginal cost is lower than the social marginal cost, which represents the reciprocal externality among the owners (users) that creates the tragedy of the commons.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: (excluders) under the cooperation in the anticommons collectively have by virtue of monopolizing the physical resources.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: That is to say, when the pervasive negative externalities are modest, cooperation between the multiple owners (excluders) in the anticommons in physical objects, even if successful, will not eliminate the tragedy of underuse.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: 12 This point is also true of the anticommons in knowledge.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For example, when patents are blocking, efficiency would be improved by their joint use, which "could be brought about either by the sale of all the patents to a single firm (whether one of the patentees or a different firm altogether) or by a cross-licensing agreement that would permit each of the firms to use all the patents" (Landes and Posner 2003: 383).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Such joint use, however, would not be socially optimal, because the single firm would have very strong market power or the result of the cross-licensing agreement "may be to disguise a cartel as a lawful patent monopoly" (Landes and Posner 2003: 383).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: This is the reason why patent pooling and cross-licensing on the patent side or the blanket licensing on the copyright side have been targets of careful antitrust scrutiny (Landes and Posner 2003: 382, 383;Heller and Eisenberg 1998;Heller 2008: 72, 73, 196).
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Furthermore, it is particularly noteworthy that the result of the insiders' cooperation through these voluntary agreements is that access to and the free use and distribution of the "knowledge" by outside competitors and society at large will be restricted or blocked to a greater extent and therefore the positive knowledge externalities will be inhibited more significantly.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: To sum up, the anticommons in knowledge is always tragic, while the anticommons in physical objects is not necessarily so.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For society at large, the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge will be much more tragic than that in physical objects.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Heller (2008: 21, 41, 42) notes that after he (1998) proposed the possibility of an anticommons tragedy, Buchanan and Yoon (2000) "demonstrated my anticommons hypothesis mathematically" and "[a]ccording to their model, society gets the highest total value from a resource . . . when a single decision maker controls its use."
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Actually, however, Buchanan and Yoon's mathematical model fails to address the full range of anticommons problems identified in Heller (1998), and the authors' suggestion that the equilibrium under either the single ownership or efficient collective management is socially optimal is misleading.
body_text.section: The Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: As mentioned in the second section of this article, Buchanan and Yoon (2000) considered neither localized negative externalities nor pervasive negative externalities in their model for commons and anticommons.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: Even when pervasive externalities are minor, their suggestion is still wrong, because the single owner has the market power, " [u]nderuse can also arise in the monopoly context, when a single owner blocks access to a resource," and this situation will also be tragic (Heller 2008: 45;Coloma 2003).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: The problem of underuse may disappear when there is perfect price discrimination (Coloma 2003), but "[i]n practice, perfect first-degree price discrimination is almost never possible" (Pindyck and Rubinfeld 2001: 373, 407).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: Even if perfect price discrimination is possible in practice, all of the consumer surplus will be captured by the monopolist as a result and it will most likely do much harm to social welfare in the long run, which is generally considered undesirable.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: It seems that although in the commons/anticommons context there is still underuse under single ownership when pervasive externalities are minor, in the anticommons context alone collecting rights into single ownership may eliminate the tragedy of the anticommons and therefore improve the situation if pervasive externalities are minor.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: However, even if concerns about the adequacy of collecting rights into single ownership as a response to the underuse problems caused by an anticommons could be overcome, other problems remain.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: In practice "it is easier to fragment than to reconvene fragmented property" (Parisi, Schulz, and Depoorter 2004; Heller 2008: 213).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: As Heller pointed out, collecting rights from an anticommons into usable private property bundles is often brutal and slow, and both markets and governments may fail to do so (Heller 1998; Heller and Eisenberg 1998).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: For example, "[l]and is much easier to break up than to put back together."
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: Eminent domain is one way to unlock the value frozen in gridlocked land, "but it's a crude solution" (Heller 2008: 110, 111).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: 13 Obviously, it is even harder to solve the cross-border anticommons tragedy at the international level resulting from fragmented sovereignty, as Adam Smith observed in 1776 in The Wealth of Nations: "The navigation of the Danube is of very little use to the different states of Bavaria, Austria and Hungary, in comparison of what it would be if any of them possessed the whole of its course till it falls into the Black Sea"(Smith 1789: book 1, chapter 3, paragraph 8; Buchanan and Yoon 2000; Heller 2008: 182, 183).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: 14 The above points seem also true of the anticommons in knowledge.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: Both markets and governments may find it difficult to dissolve barriers to knowledge production assembled under privatization.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: For example, one program can infringe many different software patents at once.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: Linux, the kernel of the GNU/Linux operating system, may have infringed as many as 283 different U.S. software patents (Stallman 2005).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: A company that developed a treatment for Alzheimer's disease found it could not bring it to market unless it bought access to dozens of patents and "[a]ny single patent owner could demand a huge payoff; some blocked the whole deal" (Heller 2008: xiii).
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: A final point to remember is that in this emerging new era of technocapitalism, 15 even if these formidable obstacles to consolidation can be overcome, the intellectual monopoly created will likely be detrimental to the diversity and dynamics of knowledge development, replacing the "tragedy" of the anticommons with the "Sargasso Sea" of monopoly.
body_text.section: Single Ownership Is Not the Way Out

body_text.text: Intellectual property rights are the source of the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: It is impossible to find a socially beneficial way to overcome the tragedy within the legal framework of intellectual property.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: As discussed above, neither "cooperation" between multiple right holders (excluders) nor collecting rights into single ownership, if possible, is a socially beneficial way to overcome the anticommons tragedy in knowledge.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: On the contrary, these partial "solutions" risk blocking the free use and distribution of knowledge to an even greater extent.

body_text.text: This is because of the negative meta-externalities of a well-established intellectual property regime.

body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Many philosophers find that privatizing and commercializing the results of scientific research-particularly patenting the results of research-is both epistemically and socially detrimental due to similar concerns (Biddle 2012).
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The only epistemically and socially beneficial solution to the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge lies in a return to a tradition of the commons.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Historically in the United States the "commons has most often referred to shared spaces that allow for free speech and the democratic process, most notably the New England town commons" (Hess and Ostrom 2006).

body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In other words, the solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons lies in its dual concept, the "knowledge commons," that is the effort to create, expand, and protect knowledge commons.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: At present, the term "knowledge commons" is "only loosely defined, ranging from jointly owned intellectual property to public property and the public domain."
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The mainstream argues that the term, when used within the intellectual arena to frequently refer to the knowledge environment for free speech, universal open access, and self-governance, is only a battle cry (Hess and Ostrom 2006).
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Research on how to create and nurture a knowledge commons, however, is well underway in the United States.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: 16 Regretfully, in China almost no attention has been paid to the "knowledge-commons" movement in the United States.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: As I pointed out in Zhou (2011), " [v] ery few people in China have the courage to doubt or oppose the accepted doctrine of intellectual property rights and the legal system of intellectual property rights as a whole from the philosophical, political, economic, and jurisprudence angles."
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: Unfortunately, the dogma of intellectual property rights prevalent in the United States is now in an even more dominant position within the intellectual arena in China than in the United States.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In this article, I use the term "knowledge commons" to refer to a knowledge environment of freedom in knowledge development and universal open access, and argue that development of the knowledge commons thus defined is the epistemically and socially beneficial solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: The knowledge commons is essentially distinct from naturalresource commons in that, as many scholars mentioned, knowledge in the knowledge commons, as a universal public good, is both nonexclusionary and nonrivalrous, while resources in naturalresource commons are more or less nonexclusionary but rivalrous (Hess and Ostrom 2006).
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: It is both nonexcludability and rivalrousness that together cause a natural-resource commons to be prone to the tragedy of overuse.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: According to Hardin (1998), there are either unmanaged commons or managed commons.
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For an unmanaged commons, "[a]s overuse of resources reduces carrying capacity, ruin is inevitable."
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: For a managed commons, it "describes either socialism or the privatism of free enterprise. Either one may work; either one may fail: 'The devil is in the details.'" Actually, however, "the privatism of free enterprise" will almost never "work."
body_text.section: How to Solve the Anticommons Tragedy in Knowledge

body_text.text: In this section, I will construct a simple model based on Bessen and Maskin's (2006) sequential model, as a metaphor for how the comedy of the knowledge commons, the ideal solution to the tragedy of the anticommons in knowledge works.

body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The former is always tragic, while the latter is not necessarily so.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: For society at large, the tragedy of the former will be much more tragic than the tragedy of the latter.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The neoliberal argument that single ownership is the socially optimal solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons is misleading.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Actually, intellectual property per se is the very source of the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons, and the tragedy is unavoidable so long as the intellectual property regime exists.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The only epistemically and socially beneficial solution to the tragedy of the knowledge anticommons is to create, expand, and protect the knowledge commons.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The comedy of the knowledge commons comes from the positive meta-externalities of performance of the knowledge commons.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Some heterodox formal models can be constructed as metaphors for how the comedy works.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Hopefully, this article with heterodox results would be a piece of writing in support of the worldwide movement for free knowledge, a new wave of which includes the Academic Spring movement starting in 2012, the Cost of Knowledge project, and the Access2Research initiative, 32 and it would also be a dissenting voice in China.
body_text.section: Conclusion
